hopobject.body:
Thought Leadership Regarding the Internet of Things
by Jason Kridner

With browsers and rich applications available to us everywhere, desires for information and control are growing astronomically. Entrepreneurial, design and cross-discipline engineering skills are all required to launch a successful connected device. Thankfully, Brian Delacy of MIT is exploring what it takes to educate individuals and teams on the required skills in the most expedient ways possible. I was fortunate to be a guest speaker at an event he hosted at MIT and to participate in a week long Independent Activities Period (IAP) class, supporting use of BeagleBone Black. This class had an amazing mix of people with different talents and interests, 

BeagleBone Black takes a central role in many developers' approach to connecting devices to the Internet, mostly thanks to its high-quality support of Linux, high-availability and extensive I/O capabilities. With Google's Dart language now running nicely, support in Canonical's announcement of Snappy Ubuntu Core for Internet Things, and uncountable IoT frameworks, possible ways to shortcut your design keep getting shorter. Learning all the relevant skills can still be rather time consuming, so it is great to see thought leaders like Brian Delacy of MIT explore how to fight through the mysteries of IoT in the most expedient way.
